2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150710110302/http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/missions/profile.cfm?Sort=Target&Target=Jupiter&MCode=EuropaFlyby|archive-date=July 10, 2015|url-status=dead}} {{PD-notice}} (previously known as '''Europa Multiple Flyby Mission''') is an [[interplanetary mission]] in development by [[NASA]] comprising an [[Space probe|orbiter]]. Planned for launch in October 2024, the spacecraft is being developed to study the [[Galilean moons|Galilean moon]] [[Europa (moon)|Europa]] through a series of [[Flyby (spaceflight)|flybys]] while in orbit around [[Jupiter]]. This mission is a scheduled flight of the Planetary Science Division, designated a [[Large strategic science missions|Large Strategic Science Mission]], and funded under the [[Planetary Missions Program Office]]'s [[Planetary Missions Program Office|Solar System Exploration program]] as its second flight.{{cite web|last1=Wolfe|first1=Alexis|last2=McDonald|first2=Lisa|url=https://www.aip.org/fyi/2017/balance-nasa-planetary-science-missions-explored-hearing|title=Balance of NASA Planetary Science Missions Explored at Hearing|publisher=American Institute of Physics|date=July 21, 2017|access-date=May 29, 2019|archive-date=July 31, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200731023935/https://www.aip.org/fyi/2017/balance-nasa-planetary-science-missions-explored-hearing|url-status=live}}{{cite web|title=Solar System Exploration Missions List|url=https://planetarymissions.nasa.gov/missions/solar%20system%20exploration|work=Planetary Missions Program Office (PMPO)|publisher=NASA|access-date=March 27, 2018|archive-url=https://archive.today/20180327141053/https://planetarymissions.nasa.gov/missions/solar%20system%20exploration|archive-date=March 27, 2018|url-status=dead}} {{PD-notice}} It is also supported by the new [[Ocean Worlds Exploration Program]]. ''Europa Clipper'' will perform follow-up studies to those made by the ''[[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]]'' spacecraft during its eight years in Jupiter orbit, which indicated the existence of a subsurface ocean underneath Europa's ice [[Crust (geology)|crust]]. Plans to send a spacecraft to Europa were initially conceived with projects such as ''[[Europa Orbiter]]'' and ''[[Jupiter Icy Moons Orbiter]]'', in which a spacecraft would be injected into orbit around Europa. However, due to the adverse effects of [[radiation]] from [[Magnetosphere of Jupiter|Jupiter's magnetosphere]] in Europa orbit, it was decided that it would be safer to inject a spacecraft into an [[Elliptic orbit|elliptical orbit]] around Jupiter and make 44 close flybys of the moon instead. The mission began as a joint investigation between the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] (JPL) and the [[Applied Physics Laboratory]] (APL), and will be built with a scientific payload of nine instruments contributed by [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory|JPL]], [[Applied Physics Laboratory|APL]], [[Southwest Research Institute]], [[University of Texas at Austin]], [[Arizona State University]] and [[University of Colorado Boulder]]. The mission will complement [[ESA]]'s [[Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer]] launching in 2023, which will fly-by Europa twice and [[Callisto (moon)|Callisto]] multiple times before moving into orbit around [[Ganymede (moon)|Ganymede]]. The mission is scheduled to launch in October 2024 aboard a [[Falcon Heavy]], during a 21-day launch window. The spacecraft will use [[gravity assist]]s from Mars in February 2025 and Earth in December 2026, before arriving at Europa in April 2030. == History == [[File:Repeated Flybys Yield a Pole-to-Pole View of Europa.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|The flybys of Europa by a previous mission collected the data for this mosaic.]] In 1997, a ''[[Europa Orbiter]]'' mission was proposed by a team for NASA's [[Discovery Program|Discovery program]]{{cite conference|last=Bradley C. Edwards, Christopher F. Chyba, James B. Abshire, Joseph A. Burns, Paul Geissler, Alex S. Konopliv, Michael C. Malin, Steven J. Ostro, Charley Rhodes, Chuck Rudiger, Xuan-Min Shao, David E. Smith, Steven W. Squyres, Peter C. Thomas, Chauncey W. Uphoff, Gerald D. Walberg, Charles L. Werner, Charles F. Yoder, and Maria T. Zuber|title=The Europa Ocean Discovery mission|conference=Proc. SPIE 3111, Instruments, Methods, and Missions for the Investigation of Extraterrestrial Microorganisms|date=July 11, 1997|doi=10.1117/12.278778}} but was not selected. NASA's JPL announced one month after the selection of Discovery proposals that a NASA Europa orbiter mission would be conducted. JPL then invited the Discovery proposal team to be the Mission Review Committee (MRC).{{citation needed|date=September 2020}} At the same time as the proposal of the Discovery-class ''Europa Orbiter'' the robotic ''[[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]]'' spacecraft was already orbiting Jupiter. From December 8, 1995, to December 7, 1997 ''Galileo'' conducted the primary mission after entering the orbit of Jupiter. On that final date the Galileo orbiter commenced an extended mission known as the ''Galileo'' Europa Mission (GEM), which ran until December 31, 1999. This was a low-cost mission, with a budget of only US$30 million. The smaller team of about 40–50 people (one-fifth the size of the primary mission's 200-person team from 1995–1997) did not have the resources to deal with problems, but when they arose it was able to temporarily recall former team members (called "tiger teams") for intensive efforts to solve them. The spacecraft made several flybys of [[Europa (moon)|Europa]] (8), [[Callisto (moon)|Callisto]] (4) and [[Io (moon)|Io]] (2). On each flyby of the three moons it encountered, the spacecraft collected only two days' worth of data instead of the seven it had collected during the primary mission. This ''Galileo'' Europa Mission was similar to a small-scale version of what the ''Europa Clipper'' is planning to accomplish. GEM included eight flybys of Europa, ranging from {{cvt|196|to|3582|km}}, in two years.{{cite book|last=Meltzer|first=Michael|title=Mission to Jupiter: A History of the ''Galileo'' Project|year=2007|id=SP-4231|series=The NASA History Series|publisher=NASA|oclc=124150579|url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4231/sp4231.pdf|access-date=December 4, 2020|archive-date=November 28, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201128052208/https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4231/sp4231.pdf|url-status=live}} {{PD-notice}} Europa has been identified as one of the locations in the 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190908093842/http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2013/1212-europa-no-longer-a-should-but-a-must.html|url-status=live}}{{cite web|title=Alternative Energy Sources Could Support Life on Europa|url=http://www.geo.utep.edu/pub/dirksm/geobiowater/pdf/EOS27March2001.pdf|last1=Schulze-Makuch |first1=Dirk|last2=Irwin|first2=Louis following the [[Galileo (spacecraft)|''Galileo'']] spacecraft's discoveries and the independent Discovery program proposal for a Europa orbiter, JPL conducted preliminary mission studies that envisioned a capable spacecraft such as the [[Jupiter Icy Moons Orbiter]] (a US$16 billion mission concept),{{cite web|url=http://trs-new.jpl.nasa.gov/dspace/bitstream/2014/38185/1/05-3441.pdf|title=Project Prometheus final report – page 178|date=2005|access-date=January 20, 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304221142/http://trs-new.jpl.nasa.gov/dspace/bitstream/2014/38185/1/05-3441.pdf |archive-date=March 4, 2016}} {{PD-notice}} the [[Jupiter Europa Orbiter]] (a US$4.3 billion concept), an orbiter (US$2 billion concept), and a multi-flyby spacecraft: ''Europa Clipper''. A mission to Europa was recommended by the [[National Research Council (United States)|National Research Council]] in 2013. The approximate cost estimate has rose from US$2 billion in 2013 to US$4.25 billion in 2020.[https://spacenews.com/europa-clipper-passes-key-review/Europa Clipper passes key review] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010134354/https://spacenews.com/europa-clipper-instrument-change-could-affect-mission-science/ |date=October 10, 2022 }}, Jeff Foust, ''SpaceNews'', Objectives == [[File:Photo composite of suspected water plumes on Europa.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|The photo composite of suspected water plumes on Europa]] [[File:EuropaClipper.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|The concept to achieve global-regional coverage of Europa during successive flybys]] The goals of ''Europa Clipper'' are to explore Europa, investigate its [[Habitability of natural satellites|habitability]] and aid in the selection of a landing site for the future [[Europa Lander (NASA)|Europa Lander]].{{cite journal|title=Science Potential from a Europa Lander|journal=Astrobiology|year=2013|first1=Robert T.|last1=Pappalardo|first2=S.|last2=Vance|first3=F.|last3=Bagenal|first4=B.G.|last4=Bills|first5=D.L.|last5=Blaney|first6=D.D.|last6=Blankenship|first7=W.B.|last7=Brinckerhoff|first8=J.E.P.|last8=Connerney|volume=13|issue=8|pages=740–73|doi=10.1089/ast.2013.1003|pmid=23924246|last9=Hand|first9=K.P.|last10=Hoehler|first10=T.M.|last11=Leisner|first11=J.S.|last12=Kurth|first12=W.S.|last13=McGrath|first13=M.A.|last14=Mellon|first14=M.T.|last15=Moore|first15=J.M.|last16=Patterson|first16=G.W.|last17=Prockter|first17=L.M.|last18=Senske|first18=D.A.|last19=Schmidt|first19=B.E.|last20=Shock|first20=E.L.|last21=Smith|first21=D.E.|last22=Soderlund|first22=K.M.|bibcode=2013AsBio..13..740P|url=https://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/1721.1/81431/2/Pappalardo_Science-potential.pdf|hdl=1721.1/81431|hdl-access=free|access-date=October 1, 2019|archive-date=October 10, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010134353/https://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/handle/1721.1/81431/Pappalardo_Science-potential.pdf;jsessionid=FC7BE20FBB7C0C9AA9F45BDF32F8E03D?sequence=2|url-status=live}} This exploration is focused on understanding the three main requirements for life: [[Water|liquid water]], [[chemistry]], and [[energy]].{{cite conference|last1=Bayer|first1=Todd|last2=Buffington|first2=Brent|last3=Castet|first3=Jean-Francois |last4=Jackson|first4=Maddalena|last5=Lee|first5=Gene|last6=Lewis|first6=Kari|last7=Kastner|first7=Jason|last8=Schimmels|first8=Kathy|last9=Kirby|first9=Karen|title=2017 IEEE Aerospace Conference |chapter=Europa mission update: Beyond payload selection|location=Big Sky, Montana|conference=2017 IEEE Aerospace Conference|date=March 4, 2017|pages=1–12 |isbn=978-1-5090-1613-6|doi=10.1109/AERO.2017.7943832}} Specifically, the objectives are to study: * Ice shell and ocean: Confirm the existence, and characterize the nature, of water within or beneath the ice, and processes of surface-ice-ocean exchange * Composition: Distribution and chemistry of key compounds and the links to ocean composition * Geology: Characteristics and formation of surface features, including sites of recent or current activity. === Strategy === [[File:Europa_Clipper_Radiation.png|thumb|upright=1.1|left|A wide orbit of Jupiter with several flybys of Europa will minimize radiation exposure and increase data transfer speed.]] Because Europa lies well within the harsh radiation fields surrounding Jupiter, even a radiation-hardened spacecraft in near orbit would be functional for just a few months.{{cite news|last=Kane|first=Van|url=http://www.planetary.org/blogs/guest-blogs/van-kane/20140826-europa-how-less-can-be-more.html|title=Europa: How Less Can Be More|publisher=Planetary Society|date=August 26, 2014|access-date=August 29, 2014|archive-date=November 17, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191117080735/https://www.planetary.org/blogs/guest-blogs/van-kane/20140826-europa-how-less-can-be-more.html|url-status=live}} Most instruments can gather data far faster than the communications system can transmit it to Earth because there are a limited number of antennas available on Earth to receive the scientific data. Therefore, another key limiting factor on science for a Europa orbiter is the time available to return data to Earth. In contrast, the amount of time during which the instruments can make close-up observations is less important. Studies by scientists from the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] show that by performing several flybys with many months to return data, the ''Europa Clipper'' concept will enable a US$2 billion mission to conduct the most crucial measurements of the cancelled US$4.3 billion [[Jupiter Europa Orbiter]] concept. Between each of the flybys, the spacecraft will have seven to ten days to transmit data stored during each brief encounter. That will let the spacecraft have up to a year of time to transmit its data compared to just 30 days for an orbiter. The result will be almost three times as much data returned to [[Earth]], while reducing exposure to radiation. The ''Europa Clipper'' will not orbit Europa, but instead orbit [[Jupiter]] and conduct 44 [[List of planetary flybys|flyby]]s of Europa at altitudes from {{cvt|25|to|2700|km}} each during its 3.5-year mission.{{cite journal|title=Europa Clipper Mission Concept|publisher=Eos Transactions American Geophysical Union|date=May 20, 2014|last1=Phillips|first1=Cynthia B.|author1-link=Cynthia B. Phillips|last2=Pappalardo|first2=Robert T.|journal=Eos Transactions|volume=95|issue=20|pages=165–167|doi=10.1002/2014EO200002 |bibcode=2014EOSTr..95..165P|doi-access=free}}{{cite web|url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/missions/europa-clipper/|title=Europa Clipper|publisher=NASA (JPL)|access-date=January 2, 2019|archive-date=March 23, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210323162742/https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/missions/europa-clipper|url-status=live}} {{PD-notice}} A key feature of the mission concept is that the ''Clipper'' would use [[gravity assist]]s from [[Europa (moon)|Europa]], [[Ganymede (moon)|Ganymede]] and [[Callisto (moon)|Callisto]] to change its trajectory, allowing the spacecraft to return to a different close approach point with each flyby.[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2014EO200002/pdf Europa Clipper Mission Concept: Exploring Jupiter's Ocean Moon] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819222413/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2014EO200002/pdf |date=August 19, 2014 }}, [[Cynthia B. Phillips]], and Robert T. Pappalardo. ''Eos, Transactions American Geophysical Union'', Volume 95, Issue 20, May 20, 2014 Each flyby would cover a different sector of Europa in order to achieve a medium-quality global topographic survey, including ice thickness.{{cite news|first=Van|last=Kane|title=Europa Clipper Update|url=http://futureplanets.blogspot.com/2013/05/europa-clipper-update.html|publisher=Future Planetary Exploration|date=May 26, 2013|access-date=December 13, 2013|archive-date=February 4, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210204070619/http://futureplanets.blogspot.com/2013/05/europa-clipper-update.html|url-status=live}} The ''Europa Clipper'' could conceivably flyby at low altitude through the plumes of water vapor erupting from the moon's ice crust, thus sampling its subsurface ocean without having to land on the surface and drill through the ice. Shielding from Jupiter's harsh radiation belt will be provided by a radiation vault with {{convert|0.3|in|mm}} thick aluminum alloy walls, which will enclose the spacecraft electronics.cite web|url=https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/meet-europa-clipper/|title=Meet Europa Clipper|publisher=NASA|access-date=November 11, 2022 To maximize the effectiveness of this shielding, the electronics will also be nested in the core of the spacecraft for additional radiation protection. == Design and construction == [[File:Europa Clipper spacecraft best 140912jpg.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|The spacecraft will make close flybys of Jupiter's moon, Europa.]] [[File:Magnetic Field of the Europa Clipper Spacecraft.gif|thumb|upright=1.0|right|Magnetic Field of the Europa Clipper Spacecraft]] === Power === Both [[radioisotope thermoelectric generator]] (RTG) and [[photovoltaics|photovoltaic]] power sources were assessed to power the orbiter.A. Eremenko ''et al.'', "Europa Clipper spacecraft configuration evolution", ''2014 IEEE Aerospace Conference'', pp. 1–13, Big Sky, MT, March 1–8, 2014 Although solar power is only 4% as intense at Jupiter as it is in Earth's orbit, powering a Jupiter orbital spacecraft by [[Solar panels on spacecraft|solar panels]] was demonstrated by the [[Juno (spacecraft)|''Juno'' mission]]. The alternative to solar panels was a [[multi-mission radioisotope thermoelectric generator]] (MMRTG), fueled with [[plutonium-238]]. The power source has already been demonstrated in the [[Mars Science Laboratory]] (MSL) mission. Five units were available, with one reserved for the [[Mars 2020 rover mission]] and another as backup. In September 2013, it was decided that the solar array was the less expensive option to power the spacecraft, and on October 3, 2014, it was announced that solar panels were chosen to power ''Europa Clipper''. The mission's designers determined that solar power was both cheaper than plutonium and practical to use on the spacecraft. Despite the increased weight of solar panels compared to plutonium-powered generators, the vehicle's mass had been projected to still be within acceptable launch limits.{{cite web|url=http://spacenews.com/42121europa-clipper-opts-for-solar-power-over-nuclear/|title=Europa Clipper Opts for Solar Power over Nuclear|first=Jeff|last=Foust|publisher=SpaceNews|date=October 8, 2014|access-date=February 8, 2015|archive-date=October 10, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010134354/https://spacenews.com/42121europa-clipper-opts-for-solar-power-over-nuclear/|url-status=live}} Initial analysis suggest that each panel will have a surface area of {{cvt|18|sqm}} and produce 150 watts continuously when pointed towards the Sun while orbiting Jupiter.{{cite news|first=Casey|last=Dreier|title=NASA's Europa Mission Concept Rejects ASRGs – May Use Solar Panels at Jupiter Instead|date=September 5, 2013|url=http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2013/20130905-no-asrgs-for-europa.html|publisher=The Planetary Society|access-date=December 13, 2013|archive-date=July 10, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180710011405/http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2013/20130905-no-asrgs-for-europa.html|url-status=live}} While in Europa's shadow, batteries will enable the spacecraft to continue gathering data. However, [[ionizing radiation]] can damage solar panels. The ''Europa Clipper''{{'s}} orbit will pass through Jupiter's intense magnetosphere, which is expected to gradually degrade the solar panels as the mission progresses. The solar panels will be provided by [[Airbus Defence and Space]], [[Netherlands]].{{cite newsletter|url=https://europa.nasa.gov/system/internal_resources/details/original/116_Europa-Clipper-Newsletter-External-vol2issue1_FINAL.pdf|title=Spacecraft Highlights|work=The Sextant – Europa Clipper Newsletter|publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory|volume=2|issue=1|page=3|date=March 2018|access-date=September 20, 2018|archive-date=October 10, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010134354/https://europa.nasa.gov/system/internal_resources/details/original/116_Europa-Clipper-Newsletter-External-vol2issue1_FINAL.pdf|url-status=live}} {{PD-notice}} === Scientific payload === The ''Europa Clipper'' mission is equipped with a sophisticated suite of 9 instruments to study Europa's interior and [[ocean]], [[geology]], [[chemistry]], and [[habitability]]. The electronic components will be protected from the intense radiation by a 150-kilogram [[titanium]] and aluminum shield. The spacecraft payload and trajectory are subject to change as the mission design matures.{{cite conference|last1=Amato|first1=Michael J.|last2=Spidaliere|first2=P.|last3=Mahaffy|first3=P.|title=Biosignature Explorer for Europa (BEE) Probe – The Concept for Directly Searching for Life Evidence on Europa at Lower Cost and Risk|url=http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/2602.pdf|conference=47th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference|year=2016|access-date=September 28, 2016|archive-date=January 22, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170122232905/http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/2602.pdf|url-status=live}} The nine science instruments for the orbiter, announced in May 2015, have an estimated total mass of {{cvt|82|kg}} and are listed below:{{cite news|url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4598|title=NASA's Europa Mission Begins with Selection of Science Instruments|publisher=NASA (JPL)|date=May 26, 2015|access-date=May 27, 2015|archive-date=September 26, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200926192203/https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4598|url-status=live}} {{PD-notice}} ==== Europa Thermal Emission Imaging System (E-THEMIS) ==== The [[Europa Thermal Emission Imaging System]] will provide high spatial resolution as well as multi-spectral imaging of the surface of Europa in the [[Infrared|mid]] to [[far infrared]] bands to help detect geologically active sites and areas, such as potential vents erupting plumes of water into space. This instrument is derived from the [[Thermal Emission Imaging System]] (THEMIS) on the ''[[2001 Mars Odyssey]]'' orbiter, also developed by Philip Christensen.{{Cite web|title=E-THEMIS {{!}} Christensen Research Group|url=http://christensen.asu.edu/instrument/e-themis/|access-date=May 14, 2021|website=Christensen Research Group|date=April 25, 2019|publisher=[[Arizona State University]]|archive-date=October 10, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010134358/https://christensen.asu.edu/instrument/e-themis/|url-status=live}} * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Philip Christensen, [[Arizona State University]]}} ==== Mapping Imaging Spectrometer for Europa (MISE) ==== The [[Mapping Imaging Spectrometer for Europa]] is an imaging [[Infrared spectroscopy|near infrared spectrometer]] to probe the surface composition of Europa, identifying and mapping the distributions of [[organic compound|organics]] (including [[amino acid]]s and [[tholin]]s[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017AAS...22913804W MISE: A Search for Organics on Europa] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181116052227/http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017AAS...22913804W |date=November 16, 2018 }}, Whalen, Kelly; Lunine, Jonathan I.; Blaney, Diana L.; ''American Astronomical Society'', AAS Meeting #229, id.138.04, January 2017{{cite news|url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4602|title=Europa Mission to Probe Magnetic Field and Chemistry|publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory|date=May 27, 2015|access-date=October 23, 2017|archive-date=December 2, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201202163713/https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4602|url-status=live}} {{PD-notice}}), salts, acid hydrates, water ice phases, and other materials. From these measurements, scientists expect to be able to relate the moon's surface composition to the habitability of its ocean.{{cite news|last=Blaney|first=Diana L. |title=Europa Composition Using Visible to Short Wavelength Infrared Spectroscopy|work=JPL|publisher=American Astronomical Society, DPS meeting #42, #26.04; Bulletin of the American Astronomical Society, Vol. 42, page 1025|date=2010}} MISE is built in collaboration with the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory (APL). * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Diana Blaney, [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]}} ==== Europa Imaging System (EIS) ==== The [[Europa Imaging System]] is a [[visible spectrum]] wide and narrow angle camera instrument that will map most of Europa at {{cvt|50|m}} resolution, and will provide images of selected surface areas at up to {{cvt|0.5|m|in}} resolution.{{cite web|last1=Turtle|first1=Elizabeth|author-link=Elizabeth Turtle|last2=Mcewen|first2=Alfred|author-link2=Alfred McEwen|last3=Collins|first3=G.|last4=Fletcher|first4=L.|last5=Hansen|first5=C.|last6=Hayes|first6=A.|last7=Hurford|first7=T.|last8=Kirk|first8=R.|last9=Mlinar|first9=A.C.|title=THE EUROPA IMAGING SYSTEM (EIS): HIGH RESOLUTION IMAGING AND TOPOGRAPHY TO INVESTIGATE EUROPA'S GEOLOGY, ICE SHELL, AND POTENTIAL FOR CURRENT ACTIVITY.|url=https://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/1626.pdf|access-date=May 14, 2021|publisher=Universities Space Research Association|archive-date=March 5, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210305231100/https://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/1626.pdf|url-status=live}} * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Elizabeth Turtle, [[Applied Physics Laboratory]]}} ==== Europa Ultraviolet Spectrograph (Europa-UVS) ==== The [[Europa Ultraviolet Spectrograph]] instrument will be able to detect small plumes and will provide valuable data about the composition and dynamics of the moon's [[exosphere]]. The principal investigator Kurt Retherford was part of a group that discovered plumes erupting from Europa while using the [[Hubble Space Telescope]] in the [[Ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy|UV spectrum]].{{cite journal|last=Roth |first=Lorenz|year=2014|title=Transient Water Vapor at Europa's South Pole|journal=Science|volume=343|issue=171|pages=171–4|doi=10.1126/science.1247051|issn=1095-9203|pmid=24336567|bibcode=2014Sci...343..171R |s2cid=27428538}}|access-date=May 27, 2015 * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Kurt Retherford, [[Southwest Research Institute]]}} ==== Radar for Europa Assessment and Sounding: Ocean to Near-surface (REASON) ==== The [[Radar for Europa Assessment and Sounding: Ocean to Near-surface]] (REASON){{cite news|url=http://astrobiology.com/2015/06/radar-techniques-used-in-antarctica-will-scour-europa-for-life-supporting-environments.html|title=Radar Techniques Used in Antarctica Will Scour Europa for Life-Supporting Environments|publisher=University of Texas Austin|date=June 1, 2015|access-date=June 4, 2015|archive-date=November 15, 2015|archive-url=https://archive.is/20151115171717/http://astrobiology.com/2015/06/radar-techniques-used-in-antarctica-will-scour-europa-for-life-supporting-environments.html|url-status=live}}{{cite journal|last1=Grima|first1=Cyril|last2=Schroeder|first2=Dustin|last3=Blakenship|first3=Donald D.|last4=Young|first4=Duncan A.|title=Planetary landing-zone reconnaissance using ice-penetrating radar data: Concept validation in Antarctica|journal=Planetary and Space Science|volume=103|pages=191–204|bibcode=2014P&SS..103..191G|doi=10.1016/j.pss.2014.07.018|doi-access=free|date=November 15, 2014}} is a dual-frequency [[Radioglaciology|ice penetrating radar]] instrument that is designed to characterize and sound Europa's ice crust from the near-surface to the ocean, revealing the hidden structure of Europa's ice shell and potential water pockets within. This instrument will be built by [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]. * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Donald Blankenship, [[University of Texas at Austin]]}} ==== Interior Characterization of Europa using Magnetometry (ICEMAG) ==== The [[Interior Characterization of Europa using Magnetometry]] (ICEMAG) was '''cancelled''' due to cost overruns.{{cite web|last=Foust|first=Jeff|url=https://spacenews.com/nasa-to-replace-europa-clipper-instrument/|title=NASA to replace Europa Clipper instrument|date=March 6, 2019|publisher=SpaceNews|access-date=April 26, 2019|archive-date=October 10, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010134356/https://spacenews.com/nasa-to-replace-europa-clipper-instrument/|url-status=live}} ICEMAG will be replaced by a simpler magnetometer.{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/jpl/nasa-seeks-new-options-for-science-instrument-on-europa-clipper/|title=NASA Seeks New Options for Science Instrument on Europa Clipper|publisher=NASA|date=March 5, 2019|access-date=March 13, 2019|archive-date=February 19, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210219064432/https://www.nasa.gov/feature/jpl/nasa-seeks-new-options-for-science-instrument-on-europa-clipper/|url-status=live}} {{PD-notice}} ==== Europa Clipper Magnetometer (ECM) ==== Replacing the ICEMAG instrument, [[Europa Clipper Magnetometer]] (ECM) will be used to characterize the magnetic fields around Europa. The instrument consists of three magnetic flux gates placed along a 25ft boom, which will be stowed during launch and deployed afterwards.{{cite web|url=https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments/ecm/|title=ECM Instruments- NASA's Europa Clipper|publisher=NASA|access-date=October 11, 2022}} By studying the strength and orientation of Europa's magnetic field over multiple flybys, scientists hope to be able to confirm the existence of Europa's subsurface ocean, as well as characterize the thickness of its icy crust and measure the water's depth and salinity.{{cite web|url=https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments/ecm/#otp_how_we'll_use_it|title=ECM: How We'll Use It |publisher=NASA|access-date=October 11, 2022}} * {{small|'''Instrument Team Lead:''' Margaret Kivelson, [[University of Michigan]]}} ==== Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding (PIMS) ==== [[File:Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding (PIMS).tif|thumb|Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding (PIMS). Pictured in a clean room at APL are the recently assembled Faraday cup sensors and instrument housings in two configurations. On the left is the final flight hardware, with insulating thermal blankets installed; on the right is a test configuration that protects sensitive hardware for transportation.]] The [[Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding]] (PIMS) measures the [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] surrounding Europa to characterise the magnetic fields generated by plasma currents. These plasma currents mask the [[Electromagnetic induction|magnetic induction]] response of Europa's subsurface ocean. In conjunction with a magnetometer, it is key to determining Europa's ice shell thickness, ocean depth, and salinity. PIMS will also probe the mechanisms responsible for weathering and releasing material from Europa's surface into the [[atmosphere]] and [[ionosphere]] and understanding how Europa influences its local space environment and Jupiter's [[magnetosphere]].{{cite conference|url=https://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/icyworlds2014/pdf/4032.pdf|title=The Influence of Magnetospheric Plasma on Magnetic Sounding of Europa's Interior Oceans|conference=Workshop on the Habitability of Icy Worlds (2014)|last1=Westlake|first1=Joseph|last2=Rymer|first2=A. M.|last3=Kasper|first3=J. C.|last4=McNutt|first4=R. L.|last5=Smith|first5=H. T.|last6=Stevens|first6=M. L.|last7=Parker|first7=C.|last8=Case|first8=A. W.|last9=Ho|first9=G. C.|last10=Mitchell|first10=D. G.|date=2014|access-date=May 27, 2015|archive-date=June 10, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610204847/http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/icyworlds2014/pdf/4032.pdf|url-status=live}}{{cite journal|last=Joseph|first=Westlake|date=December 14, 2015|title=The Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding (PIMS): Enabling Required Plasma Measurements for the Exploration of Europa|journal=AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts|volume=2015|pages=P13E–09|url=https://agu.confex.com/agu/fm15/webprogram/Paper66117.html|publisher=AGU|bibcode=2015AGUFM.P13E..09W|access-date=June 21, 2016|archive-date=January 23, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170123035543/https://agu.confex.com/agu/fm15/webprogram/Paper66117.html|url-status=live}} * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Joseph Westlake, [[Applied Physics Laboratory]]}} ==== Mass Spectrometer for Planetary Exploration (MASPEX) ==== The [[Mass Spectrometer for Planetary Exploration]] (MASPEX) will determine the composition of the surface and subsurface ocean by measuring Europa's extremely tenuous atmosphere and any surface materials ejected into space. Jack Waite, who led development of MASPEX, was also Science Team Lead of the [[Cassini–Huygens|Ion and Neutral Mass Spectrometer]] (INMS) on the ''[[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]]'' spacecraft.{{Cite web|title=Mass Spectrometer for Planetary Exploration / Europa (MASPEX)|url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experiment/display.action?id=EUROPA-CL-08|access-date=May 18, 2021|website=[[NASA Space Science Data Coordinated Archive]]|publisher=[[NASA]]|archive-date=May 19, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210519011818/https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experiment/display.action?id=EUROPA-CL-08|url-status=live}}{{Cite web|last1=Waite|first1=Jack|last2=Lewis|first2=W.|last3=Kasprzak|first3=W.|last4=Anicich|first4=V.|last5=Block|first5=B.|last6=Cravens|first6=T.|last7=Fletcher|first7=G.|last8=Ip|first8=W.|last9=Luhmann|first9=J|date=August 13, 1998|title=THE CASSINI ION AND NEUTRAL MASS SPECTROMETER (INMS) INVESTIGATION|url=https://www.lpl.arizona.edu/~yelle/eprints/Waite04a.pdf|access-date=May 18, 2021|website=[[Lunar and Planetary Laboratory]]|publisher=[[University of Arizona]]|archive-date=December 28, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211228164227/https://www.lpl.arizona.edu/~yelle/eprints/Waite04a.pdf|url-status=live}} * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Jim Burch, [[Southwest Research Institute]]}} ==== Surface Dust Analyzer (SUDA) ==== The [[Surface Dust Analyser|SUrface Dust Analyzer]] (SUDA) is a [[Mass spectrometry|mass spectrometer]] that will measure the composition of small solid particles ejected from Europa, providing the opportunity to directly sample the surface and potential plumes on low-altitude flybys. The instrument is capable of identifying traces of organic and inorganic compounds in the ice of ejecta.{{cite journal|title=Linear high resolution dust mass spectrometer for a mission to the Galilean satellites|journal=Planetary and Space Science|date=May 2012|last=Kempf|first=Sascha|volume=65 |issue=1|pages=10–20|doi=10.1016/j.pss.2011.12.019|display-authors=etal|bibcode=2012P&SS...65...10K}} * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Sascha Kempf, [[University of Colorado Boulder]]}} ==== Gravity/Radio Science ==== While not intended for use specifically as an instrument, Clipper will be using its radio antenna to perform additional experiments and learn about Europa's gravitational field. As the spacecraft performs each of its 45 flybys, its trajectory will be subtly altered by the moon's gravity. By sending radio signals between earth and the moon and characterizing the [[Doppler Shift]] in the return signal, scientists at JPL will be able to create a detailed characterization of the spacecraft's motion. This data will help to determine how the moon is flexing in relation to its distance from Jupiter, which will in turn reveal information about the moon's internal structure and tidal motions. {{cite web|url=https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments/gravity-radio-science/|title=Gravity/Radio Science Instruments|publisher=NASA|access-date=November 12, 2022}} * {{small|'''Team lead:''' Erwan Mazarico [[Goddard Space Flight Center]]}} === Proposed secondary elements === [[File:CubeSat in hand.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|A 1U [[CubeSat]] is a 10 cm cube.]] The ''Europa Clipper'' mission considered an extra mass of about {{convert|250|kg|lbs}} to carry an additional flight element. About a dozen proposals have been suggested but none went beyond the concept study phase and none are planned for the Europa Clipper mission. A few of which are described next: ==== Nanosatellites ==== Since the ''Europa Clipper'' mission may not be able to easily modify its orbital trajectory or altitude to fly through the episodic water [[Europa (moon)#Plumes|plumes]], scientists and engineers working on the mission have investigated deploying from the spacecraft several [[miniaturized satellite]]s of the [[CubeSat]] format, possibly driven by [[ion thruster]]s, to fly through the plumes and assess the habitability of Europa's internal ocean.{{cite news|url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4330|title=JPL Selects These concepts were funded for preliminary studies but none were considered for hardware development or flight. The ''Europa Clipper'' would have relayed signals from the nanosatellites back to [[Earth]]. With propulsion, some nanosatellites could also be capable of entering orbit around Europa. ==== Secondary orbiters ==== ===== Biosignature Explorer for Europa ===== NASA was also assessing the release of an additional {{cvt|250|kg}} probe called ''Biosignature Explorer for Europa'' (BEE), that would have been equipped with a basic bi-propellant engine and cold gas thrusters to be more agile and responsive to the episodic activity on Europa and sample and analyze the water plumes for [[biosignature]]s and life evidence before they are destroyed by radiation. The BEE plume probe would have been equipped with a proven [[Mass spectrometry|mass spectrometer]] combined with [[Gas chromatography|gas chromatograph]] separation. It would also carry an [[ultraviolet]] (UV) plume targeting camera as well as [[Visible spectrum|visible]] and [[infrared camera]]s to image the active region with better resolution than the ''Clipper'' mother ship instruments. The BEE probe would have flown through at {{cvt|2|to|10|km|mi}} altitude, then made a quick exit and performed its analysis far from the radiation belts. ===== Europa Tomography Probe ===== A European proposal, the Europa Tomography Probe, was a concept for an independent powered spacecraft equipped with a [[magnetometer]] that would orbit Europa on a polar orbit for at least six months. It would have determined the deep interior structure of Europa and provided a good determination of the ice shell thickness and ocean depth, which arguably cannot be done accurately by multiple flybys. ==== Impactor probes ==== Some proposed impactor probe concepts include those by the [[Netherlands]],[https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11038-017-9508-7, An Impacting Descent Probe for Europa and the Other Galilean Moons of Jupiter] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010134357/https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11038-017-9508-7, |date=October 10, 2022 }}, Wurz, P., Lasi, D., Thomas, N. et al., ''Earth Moon Planets'' (2017) 120: 113, {{doi|10.1007/s11038-017-9508-7}} and [[United Kingdom]].[https://research-information.bristol.ac.uk/files/70486876/Europa.pdf Europa's small impactor flux and seismic detection predictions] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180723053355/https://research-information.bristol.ac.uk/files/70486876/Europa.pdf |date=July 23, 2018 }}, Tsu ji, D., and Teanby, N. A., (2016), ''Icarus'', 277, 39–55. {{doi |10.1016/j.icarus.2016.04.036}} ==== Flyby sample return ==== The ''Europa Life Signature Assayer'' (ELSA) concept by the [[University of Colorado]] consisted of a probe that could have been flown as a secondary payload. ELSA would have used a small impactor to create a plume of subsurface particles and catapulted them to altitudes where it would have been able to pass through to collect samples and analyze them on board.[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20170002063.pdf TRAJECTORY AND NAVIGATION DESIGN FOR AN IMPACTOR MISSION CONCEPT] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200731042441/https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20170002063.pdf |date=July 31, 2020 }}, Andres Dono Perez, Roland Burtony, Jan Stuplz, and David Mauro, 2017, NASA AAS 17-487 {{PD-notice}}[https://www.colorado.edu/aerospace/sites/default/files/attached-files/elsa_aiaa.pdf Project ELSA: Europa Lander for Science Acquisition] Grandone, Colton Hall, Daniel Johnson, Trevor Luke, Scott Mende, Daniel Nowicki, Ben Stringer, University of Colorado, Boulder, 2017 A variation of this concept is the 1996 ''Ice Clipper'', which involves a {{convert|10|kg|lb|adj=on}} impactor that would be jettisoned from the main spacecraft to impact Europa, thereby creating a debris cloud in nearby space about {{convert|100|km|mi|sp=us}} altitude, subsequently sampled by a small spacecraft on a close flyby and use Europa's gravitational force for a free return trajectory.[http://drewryanjones.com/assets/conf_paper_2016_no3.pdf Trajectories for Europa Flyby Sample Return] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200731023937/http://drewryanjones.com/assets/conf_paper_2016_no3.pdf |date=July 31, 2020 }}, Drew Ryan Discovery class sample return mission to Europa", Chris McKay et al., Proposal from NASA Ames Research Center to NASA HQ submitted December 11, 1996 {{PD-notice}} The collection mechanism is tentatively considered to be [[aerogel]] (similar to [[Stardust (spacecraft)|''Stardust'' mission]]). === Add-on lander history === An early ''Europa Clipper'' concept called for including a stationary lander about {{convert|1|m|ft|sigfig=1}} in diameter, perhaps about {{cvt|230|kg}} with a maximum of {{cvt|30|kg}} for instruments plus propellant. Suggested instruments were a [[mass spectrometer]] and a [[Raman spectrometer]] to determine the chemistry of the surface. The lander was proposed to be delivered to Europa by the main spacecraft and possibly require the [[Mars Science Laboratory#Sky crane|sky crane system]] for a high precision, soft landing near an active crevasse.{{cite news|last=Berger|first=Eric|url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/11/attempt-no-landing-there-yeah-right-were-going-to-europa/|title=Attempt no landing there? Yeah right—we're going to Europa|publisher=Ars Technica|date=November 17, 2015|pages=1–3|access-date=January 5, 2016|archive-date=January 10, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110122700/http://arstechnica.com/science/2015/11/attempt-no-landing-there-yeah-right-were-going-to-europa/|url-status=live}} The lander would have operated about 10 days on the surface using battery power. The ''Europa Clipper'' would take about three years to image 95% of the surface of Europa at about {{convert|50|m|ft}} per pixel. With this data, scientists could then find a suitable landing site. By one estimate, including a lander could add as much as US$1 billion to the mission's cost. ====Separate launch==== {{main|Europa Lander}} [[File:PIA21048 - Europa Lander Mission Concept (Artist's Rendering).jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|An artist's impression of the separately launched [[Europa Lander]] mission (2017 design)]] It was determined in February 2017 that designing a system capable of landing on a surface about which very little is known bears too much risk, and that the ''Europa Clipper'' will lay the foundation for a future landing mission by performing detailed reconnaissance first.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-receives-science-report-on-europa-lander-concept|title=NASA Receives Science Report on Europa Lander Concept|publisher=NASA|date=February 8, mission proposal in 2017: the [[Europa Lander (NASA)|Europa Lander]].{{Cite web |url=http://spacenews.com/jpl-moves-ahead-with-mars-and-europa-missions-despite-funding-uncertainty/ |title=JPL moves 2022|url=https://spacepolicyonline.com/news/nasa-to-get-24-billion-for-fy2022-more-than-last-year-but-less-than-biden-wanted/|publisher=spacepolicyonline.com|access-date=March 15, 2022|archive-date=March 13, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220313063009/https://spacepolicyonline.com/news/nasa-to-get-24-billion-for-fy2022-more-than-last-year-but-less-than-biden-wanted/|url-status=live}} == Launch and trajectory == Congress had originally mandated that ''Europa Clipper'' be launched on NASA's [[Space Launch System]] (SLS) [[super heavy-lift launch vehicle]], but [[NASA]] had requested that other vehicles be allowed to launch the spacecraft due to a foreseen lack of available SLS vehicles.{{cite web|last=Foust|first=Jeff|url=https://spacenews.com/cost-growth-prompts-changes-to-europa-clipper-instruments/|title=Cost growth prompts changes to Europa Clipper instruments|publisher=SpaceNews|date=July 10, 2020|access-date=July 10, 2020|archive-date=September 29, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210929074855/https://spacenews.com/cost-growth-prompts-changes-to-europa-clipper-instruments/|url-status=live}} The United States Congress's 2021 omnibus spending bill directed the NASA Administrator to conduct a full and open competition to select a commercial launch vehicle if the conditions to launch the probe on a SLS rocket cannot be met.{{cite news|first=Elizabeth|last=Howell|title=NASA receives US$23.3 billion for 2021 fiscal year in Congress' omnibus spending bill|date=December 22, 2020|url=https://www.space.com/nasa-2021-budget-congress-omnibus-spending-bill|publisher=SPACE.com|access-date=December 29, 2020|archive-date=January 16, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116062645/https://www.space.com/nasa-2021-budget-congress-omnibus-spending-bill|url-status=live}} A launch on a Delta IV Heavy with a gravity assist at Venus was considered.{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-to-launch-the-europa-clipper-mission-for-a-bargain-price/|title=SpaceX to launch the Europa Clipper mission for a bargain price|publisher=[[Ars Technica]]|last=Berger|first=Eric|authorlink=Eric Berger (meteorologist)|date=July 23, 2021|accessdate=October 10, 2022|archive-date=August 5, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210805032226/https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-to-launch-the-europa-clipper-mission-for-a-bargain-price/|url-status=live}} On January 25, 2021, NASA's Planetary Missions Program Office formally directed the mission team to "immediately cease efforts to maintain SLS compatibility" and move forward with a commercial launch vehicle. On February 10, 2021, it was announced that the mission would use a 5.5-year trajectory to the Jovian system, with gravity-assist maneuvers involving Mars (February 2025) and Earth (December 2026). Launch is targeted for a 21-day period between October 10 and 30, 2024, giving an arrival date in April 2030, and backup launch dates were identified in 2025 and 2026. The SLS option would have entailed a direct trajectory to Jupiter taking less than three years. One alternative to the direct trajectory was identified as using a commercial rocket such as a [[Falcon Heavy]], with a longer 6-year cruise time involving [[gravity assist]] maneuvers at [[Venus]], [[Earth]] and/or [[Mars]]. Another option was to launch on a Falcon Heavy and perform a {{convert|700|–|800|m/s|mph|adj=on|sp=us}} maneuver at insertion orbit aphelion. This launch window is open once a year and would have required only one gravity assist, with Earth, and would shorten the travel time to 4.5 years, while only needing a [[Characteristic energy|C3]] of 25–28 km2/s2.{{cite web|title=Trajectory Browser|url=https://trajbrowser.arc.nasa.gov/traj_browser.php|access-date=May 20, 2021|website=trajbrowser.arc.nasa.gov|publisher=NASA|archive-date=May 7, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210507161617/https://trajbrowser.arc.nasa.gov/traj_browser.php|url-status=live}} {{PD-notice}} In July 2021 Falcon Heavy was chosen to launch the spacecraft. Three reasons were given: launch cost, SLS availability, and "shaking". The move to Falcon Heavy saved an estimated US$2 billion in launch costs alone.{{cite web |last1=Ralph |first1=Eric |title=SpaceX Falcon Heavy to launch NASA ocean moon explorer, saving the US billions |url=https://www.teslarati.com/spacex-falcon-heavy-nasa-ocean-moon-mission/ |website=Teslarati |access-date=November 28, 2021 |archive-date=November 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211128000524/https://www.teslarati.com/spacex-falcon-heavy-nasa-ocean-moon-mission/ |url-status=live }}{{cite web |last1=Berger |first1=Eric |title=SpaceX to launch the Europa Clipper mission for a bargain price |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-to-launch-the-europa-clipper-mission-for-a-bargain-price/ |website=arstechnica |date=July 23, 2021 |access-date=November 28, 2021 |archive-date=August 5, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210805032226/https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-to-launch-the-europa-clipper-mission-for-a-bargain-price/ |url-status=live }} NASA was not sure an SLS would be available since the [[Artemis program]] would use the entire SLS production, and the SLS's use of [[solid rocket booster]]s (SRB)s intrinsically creates more vibrations in the payload than does a launcher that does not use SRBs. The cost to redesign Europa Clipper for the SLS vibratory environment was estimated at US$1 billion. {{multiple image | align = center | direction = horizontal | width = 300px | header = Animation of Europa Clipper | image1 = Animation of Europa Clipper trajectory.gif | caption1 = Around the Sun
